title: How to Plant Perennials

steps.headline: Determine when to plant perennials.
steps.description:
In most regions, the ideal time to plant perennials is mid- to late-spring so plants have the opportunity to become established before the heat of summer. Do not plant perennials while there is a chance of hard frosts or temperatures dip below 25 degrees F (-3.89 degrees C). Plant perennials in the summer, but do not allow the plants to dry out. If you choose to plant perennials in the summer, water the plants daily for 2 to 3 weeks. Plant perennials in the fall before the first frost. Perennials planted after the first frost typically do not survive because their root systems do not have time to get established before the ground freezes. Research a specific perennial to determine when its ideal planting time is. The best time to plant perennials varies depending on the species. Consult a gardening guide or ask a professional at a local garden center about the best time to plant a specific perennial plant. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/3\/32\/Plant-Perennials-Step-1Bullet3.jpg\/v4-460px-Plant-Perennials-Step-1Bullet3.jpg","bigUrl":"\/images\/thumb\/3\/32\/Plant-Perennials-Step-1Bullet3.jpg\/aid2005766-v4-728px-Plant-Perennials-Step-1Bullet3.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":"728","bigHeight":"546","licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"}

steps.headline: Evaluate where to plant perennials.
steps.description:
Perennials can be grown in almost any location in the yard or garden. For visual impact, consider planting perennials along a fence, around a tree or in a grouping in the middle of a yard. Determine how much sunlight the area receives. This will be an important factor in selecting the perennials to be grown in the location. If the planting site is in full sun (6 or more hours of direct sunlight), select sun-loving perennials. If the planting site is shaded, select perennials that thrive in shaded conditions. Because perennials vary in growing condition requirements, it is possible to find perennials for almost any location. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/1\/11\/Plant-Perennials-Step-2Bullet1.jpg\/v4-460px-Plant-Perennials-Step-2Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"\/images\/thumb\/1\/11\/Plant-Perennials-Step-2Bullet1.jpg\/aid2005766-v4-728px-Plant-Perennials-Step-2Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":"728","bigHeight":"546","licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"}

steps.headline: Remove grass and weeds from the planting area.
steps.description:
Remove grass from the planting area as applicable. The most effective way to remove grass is to dig it up using a spade or shovel. After removing the grass, consider spraying the area with an herbicide that will kill any remaining grass. Till the garden area once the grass has died. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/9\/95\/Plant-Perennials-Step-3Bullet1.jpg\/v4-460px-Plant-Perennials-Step-3Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"\/images\/thumb\/9\/95\/Plant-Perennials-Step-3Bullet1.jpg\/aid2005766-v4-728px-Plant-Perennials-Step-3Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":"728","bigHeight":"546","licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Eliminate all weeds prior to planting because they can compromise the root systems of perennials. Local garden experts can recommend products for controlling weeds common in your area. Alternatively, hand pick weeds from the area to be planted, or cover the ground with layers of newspaper or black plastic for several weeks to smother the weeds.

steps.headline: Prepare the soil for planting.
Buy perennials at local nurseries, garden centers or through online distributors or mail-order catalogs.
steps.description: Local nurseries typically sell plants raised in your geographic area, which means the plants are hardy and acclimated to the regional temperatures. Online distributors and mail-order catalogs may ship dormant roots instead live plants because they survive better through the shipping process. The dormant roots will take longer to grow, but should produce healthy plants.

steps.headline: Choose perennials that will thrive in the prepared planting bed.
Select perennials rated for your U.S.D.A.
steps.description: Plant Hardiness zone. The zones indicate which plants are suited for winter conditions in your geographic area. This is especially important when selecting perennials as they overwinter and come back year after year. If you select a plant not appropriate for your hardiness zone, it may die during the winter months. Plant hardiness zone maps are available online.

steps.headline: Consider the mature size of each perennial.
steps.description: Perennials will grow larger each year. When selecting perennials, take into account the size of the mature plant, which is not the same as the container-bound plant purchased at a local garden center.

steps.headline: Select healthy plants.
steps.description: Examine each perennial before purchasing. Choose perennials that look fresh and vigorous. Avoid leggy or floppy plants. Inspect the plant for indication of insect damage or disease, such as broken stems, bent leaves or withered leaves. If a perennial is infested with a foliage disease, it could spread into your garden and damage other plants.

steps.headline: Remove the perennial from the growing container.
steps.description:
Hold the container upside-down and shake it lightly to loosen the perennial's roots. Gently pull the plant from the container. Examine the root ball. If many roots are visible, the plant is likely rootbound. To force new growth in a rootbound plant, slice off the bottom 1/2-inch (1.27-cm) of roots using a sharp knife. With your fingers, break up the root ball by separating the roots along the side of the root ball. If you don't break up a rootbound plant, the roots may continue a circular growth pattern and stunt the plant's growth. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/7\/77\/Plant-Perennials-Step-10Bullet1.jpg\/v4-460px-Plant-Perennials-Step-10Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"\/images\/thumb\/7\/77\/Plant-Perennials-Step-10Bullet1.jpg\/aid2005766-v4-728px-Plant-Perennials-Step-10Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":"728","bigHeight":"546","licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"}

steps.headline: Dig a hole for the perennial.
steps.description: Using a shovel or garden trowel, dig a hole that is slightly wider and the same depth as the perennial container. If the perennial is planted too deep, the plant will experience stress and may not thrive.

steps.headline: Place the perennial in the hole.
steps.description: Using a garden trowel or your hands, fill in around the plant with soil. Gently tap down the soil around the plant using your hands. The root ball should be even with or slightly below the surface of the garden soil.

steps.headline: Water the perennial thoroughly.
steps.description: Water immediately after planting. Examine the plant each day for about 2 weeks while the roots become established. Make sure the soil around the plant is moist and that the perennial isn't wilting. Most perennials need daily watering during the first week, and every other day during the second week. Perennials planted during the summer may require more frequent watering.

steps.headline: Water regularly.
steps.description: Because there are so many different species of perennials, watering requirements vary based on the specific plant. Keep the soil around the perennials moist, but not soggy. To prevent fungal diseases, water in the morning or early afternoon.

steps.headline: Mulch around the perennial.
steps.description: Mulch will hold moisture in the soil and prevent weeds from growing. Apply 2 to 3 inches (5.08 to 7.62 cm) of mulch around the plants. Do not allow the mulch to actually touch the stem or branches of the plant or it may reduce air circulation necessary for healthy growth.

steps.headline: Fertilize the perennial.
steps.description: If the soil is rich and amended with organic matter, fertilizing may not be necessary. Otherwise, fertilize with either a slow release granular or liquid fertilizer as needed. Do not over fertilize perennials, which can cause root injury or kill the plants.

steps.headline: Stake tall perennials.
steps.description: Some taller perennials, such as delphiniums, peonies, phlox and hollyhocks, may require staking. To support the stems, place wooden stakes in the ground and tie stems to the stakes with twine.

steps.headline: Remove spent blooms to encourage repeat blooming.
steps.description: Regularly deadhead faded flowers to keep the plants looking healthy and promote new blooms.

steps.headline: Cut back perennials to promote new growth.
steps.description: Perennials may start to look scruffy or leggy after blooming. Most late spring and early summer perennials benefit from clipping after blooming.

steps.headline: Divide perennials every 2 to 3 years.
steps.description: Perennials will continue to grow larger each year, but their continued growth may cause crowding in a garden. To keep the plants healthy, dig perennials out of the ground and split them into smaller chunks. The best times to divide perennials is in the early spring or fall.

text:
Prepare to Plant Perennials Determine when to plant perennials. In most regions, the ideal time to plant perennials is mid- to late-spring so plants have the opportunity to become established before the heat of summer. Do not plant perennials while there is a chance of hard frosts or temperatures dip below 25 degrees F (-3.89 degrees C). Plant perennials in the summer, but do not allow the plants to dry out. If you choose to plant perennials in the summer, water the plants daily for 2 to 3 weeks. Plant perennials in the fall before the first frost. Perennials planted after the first frost typically do not survive because their root systems do not have time to get established before the ground freezes. Research a specific perennial to determine when its ideal planting time is. The best time to plant perennials varies depending on the species. Consult a gardening guide or ask a professional at a local garden center about the best time to plant a specific perennial plant. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/32/Plant-Perennials-Step-1Bullet3.jpg/v4-460px-Plant-Perennials-Step-1Bullet3.jpg","bigUrl":"/images/thumb/3/32/Plant-Perennials-Step-1Bullet3.jpg/aid2005766-v4-728px-Plant-Perennials-Step-1Bullet3.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":"728","bigHeight":"546","licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Evaluate where to plant perennials. Perennials can be grown in almost any location in the yard or garden. For visual impact, consider planting perennials along a fence, around a tree or in a grouping in the middle of a yard. Determine how much sunlight the area receives. This will be an important factor in selecting the perennials to be grown in the location. If the planting site is in full sun (6 or more hours of direct sunlight), select sun-loving perennials. If the planting site is shaded, select perennials that thrive in shaded conditions. Because perennials vary in growing condition requirements, it is possible to find perennials for almost any location. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/11/Plant-Perennials-Step-2Bullet1.jpg/v4-460px-Plant-Perennials-Step-2Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"/images/thumb/1/11/Plant-Perennials-Step-2Bullet1.jpg/aid2005766-v4-728px-Plant-Perennials-Step-2Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":"728","bigHeight":"546","licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Remove grass and weeds from the planting area. Remove grass from the planting area as applicable. The most effective way to remove grass is to dig it up using a spade or shovel. After removing the grass, consider spraying the area with an herbicide that will kill any remaining grass. Till the garden area once the grass has died. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/95/Plant-Perennials-Step-3Bullet1.jpg/v4-460px-Plant-Perennials-Step-3Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"/images/thumb/9/95/Plant-Perennials-Step-3Bullet1.jpg/aid2005766-v4-728px-Plant-Perennials-Step-3Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":"728","bigHeight":"546","licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Eliminate all weeds prior to planting because they can compromise the root systems of perennials. Local garden experts can recommend products for controlling weeds common in your area. Alternatively, hand pick weeds from the area to be planted, or cover the ground with layers of newspaper or black plastic for several weeks to smother the weeds. Prepare the soil for planting. The most important step in planting healthy perennials is preparing the soil. Most perennials prefer rich, deep, well-drained soil. Evaluate your garden soil to determine how to amend it for perennials. If your soil has high concentrations of clay, add peat, compost and sand. If your soil has high concentrations of sand, add compost to add nutrients and create a richer soil. Organic matter like manure, compost, perlite and peat moss are beneficial to most types of garden soils. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/fe/Plant-Perennials-Step-4Bullet1.jpg/v4-460px-Plant-Perennials-Step-4Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"/images/thumb/f/fe/Plant-Perennials-Step-4Bullet1.jpg/aid2005766-v4-728px-Plant-Perennials-Step-4Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":"728","bigHeight":"546","licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Dig the planting area to a minimum depth of about 8 inches (20.3 cm) using a spade or pitchfork. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/92/Plant-Perennials-Step-4Bullet2.jpg/v4-460px-Plant-Perennials-Step-4Bullet2.jpg","bigUrl":"/images/thumb/9/92/Plant-Perennials-Step-4Bullet2.jpg/aid2005766-v4-728px-Plant-Perennials-Step-4Bullet2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":"728","bigHeight":"546","licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Spread organic matter directly on top of the existing soil and work it into the ground using a shovel or pitchfork. Insert the shovel or pitchfork into the ground, pull out the shovel filled with dirt and flip the shovel over, dumping garden soil on top of the organic matter. Repeat throughout the garden area until the organic matter is thoroughly mixed into the garden soil. Select the Perennials Buy perennials at local nurseries, garden centers or through online distributors or mail-order catalogs. Local nurseries typically sell plants raised in your geographic area, which means the plants are hardy and acclimated to the regional temperatures. Online distributors and mail-order catalogs may ship dormant roots instead live plants because they survive better through the shipping process. The dormant roots will take longer to grow, but should produce healthy plants. Choose perennials that will thrive in the prepared planting bed. Most container-bound perennials at garden centers come with tags indicating growing conditions required for healthy plants. Examine the tags to ensure the perennials you purchase will grow well in the planting bed you prepared. Consider the height of each plant. Keep in mind that taller plants may block the view (and light) of shorter plants. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/00/Plant-Perennials-Step-6Bullet1.jpg/v4-460px-Plant-Perennials-Step-6Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"/images/thumb/0/00/Plant-Perennials-Step-6Bullet1.jpg/aid2005766-v4-728px-Plant-Perennials-Step-6Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":"728","bigHeight":"546","licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Consider the bloom color of the perennials. Bright colored plants can brighten up shady spots, while dark colored plants may add depth and texture to a full sun garden. Some gardeners select color palettes for their gardens. If you choose a color palette, ensure the bloom color of the perennial complements your palette. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b3/Plant-Perennials-Step-6Bullet2.jpg/v4-460px-Plant-Perennials-Step-6Bullet2.jpg","bigUrl":"/images/thumb/b/b3/Plant-Perennials-Step-6Bullet2.jpg/aid2005766-v4-728px-Plant-Perennials-Step-6Bullet2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":"728","bigHeight":"546","licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Select perennials rated for your U.S.D.A. Plant Hardiness zone. The zones indicate which plants are suited for winter conditions in your geographic area. This is especially important when selecting perennials as they overwinter and come back year after year. If you select a plant not appropriate for your hardiness zone, it may die during the winter months. Plant hardiness zone maps are available online. Consider the mature size of each perennial. Perennials will grow larger each year. When selecting perennials, take into account the size of the mature plant, which is not the same as the container-bound plant purchased at a local garden center. Select healthy plants. Examine each perennial before purchasing. Choose perennials that look fresh and vigorous. Avoid leggy or floppy plants. Inspect the plant for indication of insect damage or disease, such as broken stems, bent leaves or withered leaves. If a perennial is infested with a foliage disease, it could spread into your garden and damage other plants. Plant the Perennials Remove the perennial from the growing container. Hold the container upside-down and shake it lightly to loosen the perennial's roots. Gently pull the plant from the container. Examine the root ball. If many roots are visible, the plant is likely rootbound. To force new growth in a rootbound plant, slice off the bottom 1/2-inch (1.27-cm) of roots using a sharp knife. With your fingers, break up the root ball by separating the roots along the side of the root ball. If you don't break up a rootbound plant, the roots may continue a circular growth pattern and stunt the plant's growth. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/77/Plant-Perennials-Step-10Bullet1.jpg/v4-460px-Plant-Perennials-Step-10Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"/images/thumb/7/77/Plant-Perennials-Step-10Bullet1.jpg/aid2005766-v4-728px-Plant-Perennials-Step-10Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":"728","bigHeight":"546","licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Dig a hole for the perennial. Using a shovel or garden trowel, dig a hole that is slightly wider and the same depth as the perennial container. If the perennial is planted too deep, the plant will experience stress and may not thrive. Place the perennial in the hole. Using a garden trowel or your hands, fill in around the plant with soil. Gently tap down the soil around the plant using your hands. The root ball should be even with or slightly below the surface of the garden soil. Water the perennial thoroughly. Water immediately after planting. Examine the plant each day for about 2 weeks while the roots become established. Make sure the soil around the plant is moist and that the perennial isn't wilting. Most perennials need daily watering during the first week, and every other day during the second week. Perennials planted during the summer may require more frequent watering. Care for Perennials Water regularly. Because there are so many different species of perennials, watering requirements vary based on the specific plant. Keep the soil around the perennials moist, but not soggy. To prevent fungal diseases, water in the morning or early afternoon. Mulch around the perennial. Mulch will hold moisture in the soil and prevent weeds from growing. Apply 2 to 3 inches (5.08 to 7.62 cm) of mulch around the plants. Do not allow the mulch to actually touch the stem or branches of the plant or it may reduce air circulation necessary for healthy growth. Fertilize the perennial. If the soil is rich and amended with organic matter, fertilizing may not be necessary. Otherwise, fertilize with either a slow release granular or liquid fertilizer as needed. Do not over fertilize perennials, which can cause root injury or kill the plants. Stake tall perennials. Some taller perennials, such as delphiniums, peonies, phlox and hollyhocks, may require staking. To support the stems, place wooden stakes in the ground and tie stems to the stakes with twine. Remove spent blooms to encourage repeat blooming. Regularly deadhead faded flowers to keep the plants looking healthy and promote new blooms. Cut back perennials to promote new growth. Perennials may start to look scruffy or leggy after blooming. Most late spring and early summer perennials benefit from clipping after blooming. Divide perennials every 2 to 3 years. Perennials will continue to grow larger each year, but their continued growth may cause crowding in a garden. To keep the plants healthy, dig perennials out of the ground and split them into smaller chunks. The best times to divide perennials is in the early spring or fall.
